703752f-a.folder: Columbia Street & Lorraine Street, Brooklyn, NY

703753f-a.folder: Columbia Street & Lorraine Street, Brooklyn, NY
703753f-a.text:
(1)
Columbia Street, north from Lorraine Street. This view shows the buildings on the east side of the street, bearing numbers 519 to 499 and extending to Bush Street. The houses were razed several years later to make way for the New York City Housing Authority's Red Hook low-rent housing project.
July 11, 1932
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The housing center under construction, viewing north on
Columbia Street from Lorraine Street.
April 9, 1939
P. L. Sperr
3) Another view north on Columbia, from Lorraine.
P. L. Sperr
Octoer 26, 1939

703754f-a.folder: Columbia Street & Lorraine Street, Brooklyn, NY
703754f-a.text:
Columbia Street, north from Lorraine Street, showing at the left foreground Todd's Field. Beyond it is seen the American Can Co's buildings on Werona and Dwight Streets. View No. 2 shows homes on the north side of Bush Street ard also on Dvight Street. In the far background is also seen several skyscrapers of Manhattan.
June 9, 1938
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr

705499f-a.folder: Lorraine Street & Columbia Street, Brooklyn, NY
705499f-a.text:
Lorraine Street, west from Columbia Street, showing the Red Hook Houses, a low cost government development,
under construction.
April 9, 1939
P. L. Sperr  Views 1,2

705500f-a.folder: Lorraine Street & Columbia Street, Brooklyn, NY
705500f-a.text:
Lorraine Street, east from Columbia Street. The buildings on the north side of the street were later razed to make way for the low rent Red Hook Housing Project sponsored by the New York City Housing Authority. Views 2 and 3 show the new housing center under construction.
View 1: June 9, 1938
View 2: April 9, 1939
View 3: October 21, 1939
P. L. Sperr

705501f-a.folder: Lorraine Street & Columbia Street, Brooklyn, NY
705501f-a.text:
6l to 73 Lorraine Street, north side, between Columbis and Hicks Streets, viewing northeastward across the S. E. corner of Lorraine and Columbia Streets and shwwing several old houses that were later razed to make way for the erection of the Red Hook low cost housing development, sponsored by the New Yorl City Housing Authority.
Views 2 and 3 show number 71-73.
Views 1,2: June 25, 1931
Vie- 3: 1938
P. L. Sperr
